Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Shepherding Biomedical Microswimmers Using Magnetic Fields

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Biomedical microrobots have the potential to be functionalized to perform therapies in the body, such as chemotherapy and hyperthermia, which are targeted in a small region to avoid damage to healthy surrounding tissue and to avoid side-effects. These "microrobots" are likely to be microstructures with no computational intelligence on board, which are controlled within the patient's body by magnetic fields generated outside the body. Much of the work on magnetic microrobots to date has focused on microswimmers that use a helical propeller to swim using a method inspired by bacteria. However, promising laboratory results to date have utilized small numbers of microswimmers and have relied on imaging techniques such as cameras to track individual microswimmers, which is not practical for medical applications. This award supports fundamental research to enable swarms of microswimmers to be controlled in a complex fashion, in the absence of medical images with enough resolution to track individual microswimmers. The outcome of this award will be knowledge that will bring minimally invasive biomedical microrobots one step closer to clinical reality. The award will also provide research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and will broaden participation of underrepresented groups in engineering education.

This research will test the conjecture that the inherent dynamics of magnetic microswimmers in rotating magnetic dipole fields make it possible to shepherd a swarm of microswimmers in the absence of localization of individuals. The term "shepherding" is borrowed because the intent is to perform the same type of tasks that would be done when herding sheep. The goal is to develop basic manipulation primitives such as "move the aggregate swarm to a location,"spread out the swarm," "gather the swarm together," and "split the swarm into smaller swarms and move them to separate locations." Specific tasks include: modeling the dynamics of single swimmers; characterizing shepherding control primitives assuming identical and non-interacting swimmers; characterizing shepherding control primitives that take advantage of population variation within a swarm; modeling magnetic and hydrodynamic interactions between swimmers; and synthesizing the relative contribution of the above effects to enable complex shepherding maneuvers with actual swarms of magnetic microswimmers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this award focused on using the spatial variation of the magnetic field produced by rotating dipole fields to control swarms of microswimmers, without requiring that microswimmers within the swarm be individually localized. A rotating dipole produces a magnetic field that, at each point in space, rotates about a different axis at the same frequency of the rotating dipole. We produced a predictive model that assumed that all microswimmers in a swarm move in a direction along the local rotation axis of the field, hence they act like particles moving in a velocity field specified by the local rotation axis. Then one can examine how a continuous blob of swarm “material” would move under the action of this velocity field. For example, in a diverging velocity field, a swarm would be spread out and expand. We showed how quantifying this motion allows us to construct a control scheme, in which we choose how to rotate dipoles in a way to move and shape the swarm to a desired target location and shape. The efficacy of such a control scheme was demonstrated through numerical simulations.

 

Important fundamental knowledge needed to take advantage of the schemes described above also includes knowing how individual microswimmers of different geometries, types of magnetic material behave, as well as how microswimmers in a swarm that approach too closely might interact with one another. Therefore in the course of this project, we also studied the behavior of both achiral and helical microswimmers under magnetic rotary propulsion, the behavior of microswimmers that have permanent magnetic and soft magnetic material, and the way in which magnetic interactions between microrobots can lead them to attach to each other as modular systems.

 

In addition to the outcomes above which advance knowledge and provide intellectual merit, this project also led to broader impacts influencing societal resources and education. Four Ph.D. students were trained who were supported by the award, including two who finished their Ph.D. work during the award. These two students now work in industry positions where the quantitative and analytical skills learned during their studies are applied to business problems. Five undergraduates were given research opportunities contributing to the project. In addition, an outreach demonstration that demonstrated the difficulties associated with microscale propulsion was deployed at outreach programs for middle- and high-school students, to encourage them to pursue further education in STEM fields. During the course of this project, the outreach demonstration was enhanced to provide simulation of rotary propulsion like that used by the magnetic microswimmers studied in this project.
